All labour has dignity and the way that we give labour dignity is by paying people the respect and the value that they are worth... We have to raise the national minimum wage to $15 an hour.”Taking to&nbspTwitter&nbspafter her stint behind the bar, she wrote:&nbsp“I was nervous that I may have lost my touch - still got it! That muscle memory doesn’t quit.&nbspMs Ocasio-Cortez&nbspwas campaigning for the Raise the Wage Act 2019, a bill introduced by members of her&nbspDemocratic Party in January which would prevent tipped workers from being paid less than the federal minimum wage.&nbspUS law exempts restaurants, nail salons and car washes from paying their tipped staff the minimum wage of $7.25 (£5.93) per hour. It has not risen from that rate&nbspsince 2009.Instead they are allowed to pay just&nbsp$2.13 per hour. Employers in 43 US states, including New York, are allowed to pay workers below the federal minimum wage if they earn the full minimum wage counting tips.Created with Sketch.Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez - title: sun says baroness wheatcroft brexit tirade
story: We know there are plenty of Remainer elites who think every Leave voter must be thick. But it’s rare for one of them to come out and actually say it.The UK  “A Remain country.” Brexiteers  “They’re wrong.” Where they come from  “Not terribly pleasant.”Why did they vote out  “They’re ­uncomfortable in their own skin.” It’s delusional and demeaning.Who does this unelected non-entity think she is to lecture . million Brits  And quite what she’s doing in the Brexit-backing Tory party is a mystery to us.Does she realise it’s her arrogant attitude that meant she and her establishment mates lost in   Clearly not.Precious few Europhiles have given any thought to the reasons behind the  vote. Instead they smear just over half the country as backward-looking and beyond help.Even Michel Barnier seems to think it’s because we’re pining for the days of Empire, rather than to take control of our laws and borders.If the Second Referendum crowd really think Britain is about to change its mind — despite the huge number of votes for the Brexit Party last week — they need to think again.Every time people like Wheatcroft open their mouths, they give one more reason we’re better off out.IT is naive to think education is free.So the idea that you could deliver university courses without somebody paying just isn’t realistic.Tuition fees are necessary. The way they are paid back means youngsters who are bright enough can afford it in the long-run, without ever truly crippling them with debt.But nobody should be arguing that those who don’t go to university should be subsidising those who do, any more than they already do.There are some universities charging full-whack for sub-par courses, and because almost everybody is charging the maximum students don’t have much choice. The “market” the Government hoped for has never truly developed.But the real answer to our skills crisis Supercharging vocational education, and giving kids the skills for the st century’s technological revolution.THE Government is right to demand service station operators are transparent about pricing.They’ve been ripping off motorists for years. But the real villain at the pumps is the Treasury.It’s all very well saying fuel tax has been frozen. But drivers know it’s still far too high.Something for the Tory leadership candidates to think about... Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris rev up leadership campaign
story: Having kept a low profile for the past few days, he will unveil his most senior supporter yet, with Liz Truss, the Chief Secretary to the Treasury, set to endorse him.The Boris campaign will also unveil a slew of MPs backing him, which will put him ahead in the endorsement stakes.But just as signicant as the number supporting him is the fact that Boris’s old enemies are beginning to make peace with him. I understand that ious MPs have been to see him to say that while they won’t vote for him, they would accept his leadership.One MP who won’t be endorsing him, though, is Amber Rudd. She and Boris sat down on Thursday. But ultimately the dferences between them over Brexit policy are too great to make any kind of dream ticket work.I understand that Rudd pushed the former Foreign Secretary to budge on his commitment that the UK would leave the EU on October  with or without a deal. Johnson would not. Rudd felt that she could not support someone holding this position.Another complication was that Johnson and Rudd’s dferences on Brexit made it very hard for them to agree on a joint governing agenda. Johnson, though, should still have more votes in the first round than any other Brexiteer candidate.He needs to finish  votes clear of Dominic Raabhe is to establish himself as the clear Leave choice — Raab is more likely than him to pick up support as the second tier Brexiteer candidates drop out.As one of those backing Boris puts it: “He’s got to get as close as possible to a third on the first round.” The support of a third of MPs guarantees you a place in the members’ run-off.The problem for the former London Mayor, as this supporter acknowledges, is that “ there’s ever a perception that Boris was falling back then that would be compounded”.On the Cabinet side of the contest, Sajid Javid is attempting to reboot his campaign by today setting out his plan for how to deal with the Irish border issue.One of those backing him tells me it is “not just how you voted in the referendum, but your ability to implement no deal or negotiate with the EU” that matters. This supporter argues that Johnson and Raab aren’t going to get anything out of Brussels, while Javid might.The Cabinet side of the contest is becoming increasingly fractured. I understand that the Cabinet Ministers most opposed to No Deal have privately agreed to back either Matt Hancock or Rory Stewart in the first round. Both are running interesting campaigns.Stewart is out doing social media walkabouts, while Hancock is making arguments that the other candidates are being forced to follow. I’m told that next week he will propose a levy on betting companies to fund treatment for gambling addiction.The energy of these campaigns is causing trouble for the more established Cabinet contenders. I understand that backers of one of them are now warning MPs: “Go to bed with Hancock, wake up with Boris.”But Jeremy Hunt’s biggest problem is the sense that, in the words of one senior Tory, he is a “completely wasted place” in the final two as it is hard to see how he could beat a Brexiteer candidate.This is why a growing number of Tories think the party is “heading to the destined psycho-drama” of a Boris Gove run-off.BATTEN down the hatches, hurricane Donald is blowing into town. As his interview in this newspaper demonstrates, Donald Trump won’t be governed by the normal diplomatic conventions on his State visit.He is more than happy to make known his admiration for Boris Johnson, despite the Tory leadership contest. Though some of the rival camps think Trump’s blessing will be a double-edged sword.It is the Foreign Secretary, Jeremy Hunt, who will greet Trump on his arrival, which will give Hunt the chance to burnish his statesman credentials. Hunt will also be involved in Tuesday’s Downing Street talks between Trump and Mrs May.Penny Mordaunt, the Defence Secretary, who is expected to throw her hat into the leadership ring, will meet with the President’s daughter, Ivanka, to discuss female economic empowerment.Trump is not an easy President to deal with. But he is the leader of our closest and most important security ally. UK politicians must also realise that on ious issues, including China and the role of Huawei in G networks, the Trump position represents the new political consensus in the US.The UK would be mad to endanger its most import- ant intelligence relationship over this issue.THE next test for Nigel Farage’s Brexit Party comes on Thursday, with the Peterborough by-election.If Farage’s party can win, it will show how Brexit has redrawn the political landscape. It will give the Brexit Party a toe-hold in Parliament and a chance to become a formidable political force.Butthe Brexit Party can’t take a seat which voted heavily for Leave in the aftermath of its Labour MP being sent to prison, then its current momentum will be checked.CABINET on Tuesday has been cancelled. This is surprising given that it didn’t meet this week as Parliament was in recess. The official reason for it not taking place is that there is too much on with the Trump visit and D-Day commemorations.But as one minister points out to me, it is hard to believe that Cabinet would have been cancelledit hadn’t been for the fact that Theresa May is resigning as Tory party leader at the end of the week.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sajid javid no deal brexit leadership tory
story: The Home Secretary, who has thrown his hat in the ring to be the next Prime Minister, also added he wouldnt hold a general election as he outlined a five point plan.He outlined his Brexit plan - which also includes working with Ireland to amend the backstop and to leave on October .The -year-old referenced Margaret Thatcher in his campaign declaration, as he indicated he would carry out a hard-nosed negotiation with the EU.One of  Tory MPs vying for leadership, he told the Daily Mail: In the words of a great British prime minister who knew how to get what she wanted from the European Commission: No, no, no.The voters have been asked their opinion more than enough times. Never in this countrys history have we asked people to go to the polls a second time without implementing their verdict from the first.Mr Javid announced his candidacy in the wake of the partys disastrous Euro elections result, the worst in its history.In a video he posted online, the Bromsgrove MP - whos dubbed himself The Saj - said: Its time to rebuild trust, to find unity and to create new opportunities for our country.The Prime Minister will formally stand down as party leader on June  after announcing her resignation on May  - but will stay in place while the new PM is being chosen, rather than handing over to an interim chief such as David Lidington.The leadership contest, overseen by party chairman Brandon Lewis, will take around six weeks.But Brussels chiefs have warned the timeline wont change and the new leader wouldnt be able to tear up the current Brexit deal and simply start again.Mr Javid, whose father was a Pakistani immigrant and bus driver, called his points an honest, credible set of proposals that recognises the signicant challenges we face.The -year-old said planning for a No Deal would show the country is serious about walking away from the EU.He added: This would show the EU we are ready... so when we turn up to negotiate they know we are not afraid of walking out.If we cannot get a deal we should, with great regret, leave without one, having done everything we can to minimise disruption.Mr Javid is a lelong Eurosceptic who backed Remain in the  referendum, but has since been trying to shore up his Brexiteer credentials.He finished his bid to convince his party to back him with: Thats why we need a leader who can unite the party, and country, behind a credible plan – and then go and actually deliver it.I believe this is that plan. And I know I am that leader.Mr Javid entered Parliament in  and served as Culture Secretary, Business Secretary and Communities Secretary before being promoted to his current job last year.The frontrunner out of the  MPs is Boris Johnson with Dominic Raab, Esther McVey and Andrea Leadsom vying to take his crown as the top Brexiteer in the race.Cabinet ministers Jeremy Hunt, Michael Gove, Matt Hancock and Rory Stewart have also put their names forward.Other potential candidates for the leadership include Penny Mordaunt, James Cleverly, Graham Brady and Steve Baker.THERESA Mays resignation on Friday kickstarted the Tory leadership election.The Prime Minister will formally stand down as party leader on June  - but will stay in place while the new PM is being chosen, rather than handing over to an interim chief such as David Lidington.The leadership contest, overseen by party chairman Brandon Lewis, will take around six weeks.Any Tory MP can enter the race, and the list of contenders is then whittled down by the parliamentary party.MPs vote in multiple rounds, eliminating one candidate each time until just two are left.The partys , activists then choose behind the final shortlist of two, with the winner declared leader and Prime Minister.When Mrs May became leader, she didnt have to submit to a vote of members because Andrea Leadsom pulled out of the race.So the last time activists have had a say on the leadership was , when David Cameron defeated David Davis.

title: meghan markle prince harry diana tribute instagram
story: The Duke and Duchess of Sussex shared a photograph of Harrys late mother as they highlighted the first day of Pride Month today with their million Instagram followers.Princess Diana herself had been a key figure in changing the stigma around AIDS and HIV.Among her work, Princess Diana opened the UK’s first purpose- built HIV Aids unit, which cared exclusively for patients with the virus, at London’s Middlesex Hospital in .In front of the media, she shook the hand of a man suffering with the illness. She did so without gloves, challenging the notion that HIV Aids was passed from ­person to person by touch.And Prince Harry and Meghan Markle made sure to pay tribute to her work as they marked Pride Month, sharing a photograph of her meeting with patient Gerard McGrath at London Lighthouse in .Mr McGrath himself recounted the touching visit in , saying: When she came in, she was shining.That smile, it just beamed when she smiled. She beamed.I sound like a sycophant but that’s how it was.I’m not a royal person really, I’m a republican, but she was an exception.Other photos shared by the Sussex Royal Instagram account mentioned groups including the Elton John AIDS Foundation, the Trevor Project and Stonewall.Elton John himself had become fast friends with Princess Diana thanks to her work.Taking to social media today, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex wrote: Continuing with our tradition to rotate the accounts we follow based on causes and social issues that matter to us: For the month of June we “proudly” shine a light on PRIDE.This month we pay tribute to the accounts supporting the LGBTQ+ community - those young and old, their families and friends, accounts that reflect on the past and are hopeful for a deservedly more inclusive future.We stand with you and support you.Because it’s very simple: love is love.The post has been widely praised, with Olympic er Tom Daley writing: This is just AWESOME.Speaking to The Sun in the Oval Office, Mr Trump told of his great honour at meeting the -year-old monarch again, and how he’s ready to lock horns with the Prince of Wales on climate change.Relations with Meghan are believed to be much frostier — yet Trump was generous in his praise for the new mum.Officially she will miss next week’s s while on maternity with three-week-old son Archie.But it is thought she and Trump are being kept apart to avoid an embarrassing confrontation.LA—born Meghan, , accused him of being “misogynistic” and “isive” during his  presidential campaign.The ex-Suits actress also pledged to vote for his rival Hillary Clinton.Told of Meghan’s barbs by The Sun, Mr Trump insisted it was the first time he’d heard them.He said: “I didn’t know that. What can I say  I didn’t know that she was nasty.”Told Meghan had threatened to leave for Canadahe won in , he countered: “A lot of people are moving here .”He also revealed that he had no idea that he wouldn’t be meeting Meghan on his three-day state visit.The couple last month unfollowed Kate Middleton and Prince Williams Instagram as part of their campaign to raise awareness for social issues.And it was this week revealed the couple split from the charity set up with the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge.The young royals were dubbed the “Fab Four” but just  months after their first and only joint appearance, the couples have gone on to pursue their own charities separately.It comes as Royal fans guessed that it was Meghan Markle herself writing the Instagram posts for Sussex Royal.The new parents also used their social media  to share a sweet photo of their newborn son Archie to celebrate Mothers Day.Their social media followers recently overtook the number following Kate Middleton and Prince Williams Kensington Royal Instagram account.

title: autistic boy school september specialist condition
story: Alex Kentfield now remains in limbo as he awaits to find an institution that is equipped to deal with his condition.Little Alex was diagnosed with autism when he was just one but has since made great strides in his communication skills at nursery.His rapid improvement means he is no longer able to qualy for a place at his nursery’s specialist feeder school where his mother insists he would be “very happy”.#After being encouraged to apply to mainstream schools with specialist units, mum Daniela was horried to discover staff there were ill-equipped to deal with her son’s condition.The -year-old from Great Blakenham, Suffolk, has lambasted Suffolk County Council for failing to provide adequate support to autistic children.She said: “I’m just exhausted - the council have been so little help.“We’re totally stuck in the middle and I have no idea how things are going to work out.“I don’t understand why we’ve not been offered more support, it’s not fair.”She added that she is now intimidated by the prospect of home schooling her boy should he not find a place by September.She said: “It looks like I’ll have to teach him myself but I would need so much help and support to do that - and I can’t see him being too happy to spend all his time with me. Daniela and Gareth, , were first alerted to their son’s condition after they noticed he was frequently crying and struggling to communicate.Having already had his brother Kyle, , who does not suffer from autism, they knew instinctively Alex’s behaviour was dferent.The tot was quickly diagnosed with autism which means his ability to speak lags around  months behind his peers.He currently attends The Bridge School assessment nursery in Ipswich where his parents insist he is very settled.Daniela said: “He’s such a happy little boy and he loves attending his current school.“Autistic children don’t tend to make friends or socialise like that but he has become settled there.“We had to explain to him that he couldn’t carry on there and it’s left him really confused - he thinks he’s already been booted out.“He keeps saying ‘Bridge School says no more Alex’ - it’s hard to make him understand.”They were expecting him to start in reception class at The Bridge in September - but staff agreed Alex had developed too rapidly to qualy for a place.Now the family have been left abandoned by the council as they race to find little Alex a place.Criticising the situation, UK Autism Ambassador Anna Kennedy OBE slammed authorities for frequently leaving autistic children in “limbo”.Autism is a lelong developmental disability that affects how sufferers perceive the world and interact with others.It is a spectrum condition meaning autistic people require ious levels of support which can be critical to helping them develop and learn.There are currently around ,  autistic people in the UK - equating to  in .Suffolk Council Council have been contacted for comment.

title: champions league final madrid liverpool spurs
story: The Merseyside club won the game - thanks to an early penalty from Mo Salah and a late sealer from super substitute Divock Origi.The delirious scenes kicked off as soon as the final whistle went, while the party had been well underway in Liverpool before the game even started.Hordes of football supporters descended on the Spanish capital earlier in the day, with the total number of supporters in Madrid much higher than the , tickets made available to both sets of fans.Those not able to catch the match from inside the stadium were forced to find a pub showing the football after authorities decided the two designated fan zones should close just before kick-off, while officials ruled nowhere in the city centre should be able to show the game on a big screen.Liverpool Mayor Joe Anderson, who had written to his counterpart in Madrid to request a giant screen broadcast the match, said UEFA guidance was behind the decision.He added in a tweet on Saturday evening: Told , bars and restaurants and cafes open with screens.The historic final took place on a hot weekend of bumper sport, as Liverpool beat first-time finalists Tottenham Hotspur - the first all-English final in a top tier European club competition since .Fans who didnt make it to Madrid flooded pubs and bars across the country as Brits enjoyed a C sizzler on the hottest day of the year so far.In Spain, players competed in a roasting C pm kick-off.They were cheered on by , supporters from each side, while thousands more filled the , capacity venue.Last night at least five British football fans were arrested in Madrid as footage showed Spurs fans being battered by cops last night.It comes after cops with batons were filmed storming a city-centre bar in the Spanish capital.Nearly , officers are taking part in Operation Albion at Wanda politano stadium tonight.Those who prefer other sports are spoilt for choice - Super Saturday includes the Tottenham Hotspur versus Liverpool clash in Madrid and Anthony Joshua boxing in New York, as well as the Cricket World Cup, the Epsom Derby, the Premiership rugby final and an England women football friendly.

title: suspect cop ground officer tasered
story: The -year-old man turned violent when he was stopped by police following reports of a shopkeeper being threatened with a screwdriver during an attempted robbery.As two officers tried to arrest the suspect, he floored one with a single punch then threw the other to the ground and started beating him in front of stunned witnesses outside a Costcutter store in Penn, Wolverhampton, at around .pm on Thursday.The female officer managed to save her colleague by zapping the out-of-control suspect with a Taser, knocking him to the cobbles. He was arrested on suspicion of assaulting a police officer, theft and attempted robbery.A -year-old man was also arrested at the scene on suspicion of assault and theft.West Midlands Police said the male officer suffered cuts to his arms, legs and face and the female officer was left with bruising and swelling. Neither were seriously injured.Footage of the the attack - filmed by an onlooker - has been viewed more than , times after it was shared on social media yesterday.It shows the suspect resisting the officers as they try to handcuff him, shouting: I cant see. You sprayed me for no reason.The officers order him to get down on the ground but he replies: Why should I  I’ve done nothing f****** wrong.The suspect then wrestles the male officer to the floor and punches his female colleague in the face - who screams before hitting the pavement.The thug then starts pummelling the male officer while he is down - but he bravely manages to cling on to his attackers leg.This allows his partner time to get back to her feet and stun the suspect with her Taser, subduing him instantly.He and another man are then put in cuffs and detained at the side of the road.Social media viewers were angry that bystanders did not intervene as the officers were being attacked.Sohial Yousaf wrote: Wow, not one person helped the police. Just shocking.Steve Morgan added: People used to help the police when in a struggle, now they just watch and video them.A West Midlands Police spokesman said: Officers arrived at the scene and discovered two men who appeared to be trying to steal alcohol from the nearby Strictly Liquor store.Two officers were assaulted, causing minor injuries, and a -year-old man was Tasered and detained.He has been arrested on suspicion of assaulting a police officer, theft and attempted robbery.A -year-old man has also been arrested on suspicion of assault and theft. They both remain in police custody for questioning.Anyone with information is urged to contact the force on , quoting crime reference number WV A .

title: two guardsman faint trooping colour rehearsal
story: The soldiers had to be helped to their feet after collapsing to the ground as the mercury soared to C - making it the hottest day of the year.Three colleagues rushed to help the troops, who were in full ceremonial kit including their lb bearskin hat.Todays rehearsals come just a week before Trooping the Colour is held on June  to mark the Queens official birthday.Officers formed impressive lines and followed  dferent orders for todays Colonels Review at Horse Guards Parade by St Jamess Park.At the point of today’s review, each Guardsman will have marched more than  miles in rehearsals and taken more than half a million steps.Todays rehearsal is the second for the Trooping the Colour, with the Duke of York inspecting the troops.Its the first time that Prince Andrew, Colonel of the Grenadier Guards, will take the salute as the inspecting officer after taking over the role from his father the Duke of Edinburgh late in .Next week will see the Queen and members of the Royal Family taken down Pall Mall before watching a FAR fly-past on the balcony of Buckingham Palace.And the afternoon is only expected to get hotter with the Met Office forecasting highs of C.Trooping The Colour is a parade performed by the st Battalion Coldstream Guards on Horse Guards Parade.More than , officers and men are involved with  horses and  musicians.The procession has taken place every year the current Queen has reigned apart from  when it was cancelled.Trooping The Colour marks the Queens OFFICIAL birthday which is always the second Saturday in June.The impressive show will mark the Queens birthday

title: john mcdonnell cries brexit party
story: And while the Shadow Chancellor revealed he is a Remainer at heart he insisted he would respect the Brexit vote.The wide-ranging interview comes as the Brexit Party stormed to victory in the EU elections - smashing the Tories and Labour as they scooped nearly  per cent of the vote.Millions of voters deserted the two main parties, with Nigel Farage vowing to take power in the next General Election.But Mr McDonnell today revealed concerns over the partys meteoric rise.The -year-old told The Times Magazine: The issue for me on the Brexit Party is not where the votes are going it’s the nature of its politics.It gives a stepping stone for the far right and that’s very worrying. We had that politics in this area for a long time, with the BNP and the National Front. I wouldn’t want it to be inflicted on the rest of society.The self-admitted Marxist - who won just . per cent of the EU election votes - said he was now hoping to prepare for victory in the next General Elections.And while preparing a draft budget, he also revealed to the publication he would deliver on the Brexit vote.He explained: In my heart I’m a Remainer – I campaigned for Remain – but we have to respect the decision that was made.In the candid interview, Mr McDonnell revealed how he still considered himself working class.Now a dad of three and grandfather of five, he said he was soft when it came to parenting.And his sentimental attitude has worked its way into his political career, with the career politician admitting : I cry all the time.He said he burst into tears when Jeremy Corbyn was shortlisted for the  Labour leadership contest.But Mr McDonnell said he was most affected by the stories of his constituents, having been the MP for the Hayes and Harlington constituency since the  general election.He revealed people had even attempted to take their own lives in his office after losing their benefits, saying: You’d have a heart of stoneyou weren’t moved by that.”Known as Corbyns closest ally, Mr McDonnell revealed he was conscious of the problems faced by Labour, including concerns around anti-Semitism in the party.He said he was frustrated the party hadnt moved fast enough over the issue.Since Mr Corbyn became leader in , he has been dogged by critics claiming the party harbours anti-Semitic activists and campaigners among its membership.And this week Labour executive member Pete Willsman was suspended from the party after he was caught on camera blaming the partys anti-Semitism crisis on the Israeli embassy.In a leaked recording obtained by LBC Radio, Mr Willsman said the storm in the party was all lies and claimed party staffers were linked to the Israeli embassy.Earlier this week the Equality and Human Rights Commission said it had launched an investigation into whether the Labour party unlawfully discriminated against Jews.The party insists it has tightened up its procedures since Corbyn ally Jennie Formby took over as general secretary.A spokesman for the EHRC said: The Equality and Human Rights Commission is today launching a formal investigation to determine whether the Labour party has unlawfully discriminated against, harassed or victimised people because they are Jewish.We are pleased that the Labour party has committed to co-operate fully with this investigation.

title: parents queue cars wait buy bargain home rochdale
story: Desperate house buyers have been living in their cars, waiting for up to ten days in the hopes of snapping up a bargain plot on a new estate on Waterloo Road in Rochdale, Greater Manchester.It comes as Britain is in the grips of an affordable housing crisis , with young people and those on low incomes struggling to get a foot on the housing ladder.And the housing crisis has made the two, three and four bedroom properties - for sale from £, to £,  - all the more attractive.Among those waiting was a man - fast asleep across the front seats of his white van this morning.A sign in his window declared his claim for ‘Westmeath Plot ’ which still has no footings in place.Another empty vehicle outside the sales office had bedding in the back.Meanwhile, a family, mum, dad, and toddler, were in their taxi waiting for ‘Wicklow plot ’.The dad, who did not want to be named, told The Sun Online: We have been here for three days and our plot comes on the market today.We know some people had been waiting for  days to get the plot they want.We already have a house and we have taken it in turns to go home and eat and rest whilst their other one stays here.There is no real competition becauseyou have the sign in your car window then the next person along just bags another plot.According to latest statistics, the UK has reached a critical level and needs an extra four million homes.More than a third of Brits spend more than half their income on housing costs when they first move out.It comes after it was revealed potential buyers were bringing in sleeping bags, hot water bottles to make sure they dont lose their spot in the queue - even having pizza delivered to their cars.A determined mum from Oldham told Manchester Evening News that she had spent three nights in the car, taking turns with her family.And she revealed she is prepared to wait patiently in line for weeks for the opportunity to snap up a Gleeson home sold on a first-come first-save basis.The woman, who asked not to be named, said: Its going to be next week or the week after.They are not telling us when they will be released.She added: Why dont they just release all the houses so people can come and reserve a plot they want rather than people queuing up in a car Its just a ridiculous process.The UK is short for four million homes and to keep up with the growing demand, , new homes must be built every year until  to solve the backlog.Those new homes would be for those living on the street, tenants unable to keep up with extortionate rent, grown up children who cant afford to leave the family home and couples delaying having children because their houses are too small.According to research by Centrepoint, people aged between  and  are more likely than any generation before them to have experienced homelessness.The soaring cost of living has severely penalised Brits, with more than a third of young people spending more than half their income on housing costs when they first move out.Almost all peoplewho are now in their sixties had an income that covered their housing costs when they first left home.Just a quarterof young people today do not have enough to stretch their income to cover housing costs.In Greater Manchester,  more than , people are homeless and , in Salford.The cost of housing has increased but incomes have not kept up.Another prospective buyer, who did not want to be named, said: I’m interested in a three bedroom home and there is not a shortage of them around here.I’m just looking to see what is available so far as new build goes, but I’m happy to get an older house.I certainly wouldn’t be camping out in my car for days on end. Some of us have jobs to go to.”A spokesperson for Gleeson said: We cannot stop people sleeping in cars and we have previously tried a ticketing system, but who gets the first ticket and how We sincerely wish that we could provide a house to everyone who wants one and we are sorryany of our potential customers are disappointed.

title: alligator home kitchen florida usa
story: Mary Wischhusen, , saw the huge reptile that broke into the house in Clearwater, Florida, before it raided the kitchen after forcing its way though a low window.Mary woke up to loud noises in her kitchen at am and thought she was being burgled.The ft monster crept into her home by breaking a window and slithered onto her kitchen floor.The gator got into a stash of wine, destroyed her kitchen table, and damaged her walls.Terried, she called Clearwater Police Department for help, who rushed to the scene along with an animal trapper.Mary said it took two trappers and  police officers two hours to get the alligator out of the home, where she has lived for almost four decades.She told Tampa Bay Times: All I had was a vision of a huge head. A big head looking at me saying, ‘Hey!’I don’t know why he wanted my red wine, but he got my red wine.Clearwater Police Department communications officer, Joelle Castelli, said: Its unusual for a gator to break in like this. It was a dangerous situation.It was hissing in an aggressive manner. We did attend with an animal trapper who secured the animal and took it away.It was first spotted acting aggressively in the street by a newspaper seller.The homeowner then phoned because she thought there was an intruder.Mary says she played computer games while waiting for help to arrive.Local police tweeted footage of the raging reptile, saying: The red liquid in the video is wine, not blood.It is thought there are around . million alligators living in Florida, most of which are wild animals which live in swamps and shallow waters.Gators often come into close contact with humans and there have been many documented incidents of alligators finding their way into swimming pools and gardens.On this occasion, the animal trapper successfully managed to safely secure the alligator by taping its mouth shut.It was taken away and will be released back into the wild.Earlier this week, a woman had her leg ripped open by a huge eight foot-long alligator while she was out swimming in lake in the same state.Nichole Tillman, , from Melbourne, Florida, suffered serious injuries over the holiday weekend and had to be airlted from Lake Wilderness Park in Cocoa.The gator, which was reportedly -foot--inches long, attacked Nichole while she was out taking a dip at the popular swimming spot.

title: priti patel end the brexit betrayal
story: We have just experienced the worst national election results in our long and successful electoral history after a cataclysmic series of polls since Theresa May and her entire Cabinet broke their promise - which they made on over one hundred occasions - to leave the EU on th March.Voters in the country are rightly angry at broken promises by the Conservative leadership about leaving on time, about leaving the single market, and about leaving the customs union.They witnessed with disbelief as the Cabinet supported Theresa May negotiating with the most left-wing leader of the Labour Party in its history in a bizarre attempt to agree a sordid deal which would have betrayed the country’s vote for a genuine Brexit.Conservative Party members have witnessed first-hand the level of public distrust and anger during the recent local government elections.Hard working Councillors and candidates lost seats because of the failings of this Cabinet and through no fault of their own.Now they rightly expect their Conservative MPs to get their act together and elect a Leader who will break the mould of the same old broken politics of the Westminster blob and take us out of the EU and make the Conservative Party Conservative again.There is a common denominator in the above examples of bad faith and incompetence. That is the Cabinet.It is not only Theresa May who let down Conservative Party voters, members and supporters.She was abetted and supported by her Cabinet. In this country we operate a system of collective responsibility and it is not good enough for Cabinet members now to claim they held a dferent view or would have done things dferently.How can it be right that Cabinet Ministers, who were complicit with the failed Brexit polices of Chequers, the Withdrawal Agreement and the subsequent betrayal of Brexit, credibly seek to claim they are an acceptable choice for this role They were sat around the top table when decisions were made and must take responsibility for them.I would sup with a very long spoon indeed with those who are complicit but now claiming they can offer the Party new leadership and direction.The British public are not stupid and our Party members know what they are voting for.They wont be fooled by those born-again ‘Leavers’, who trumpet their devotion to Brexit even though they have done nothing for the last three years to advance theof British sovereignty.The British public and our long suffering Party members know where the responsibility for the greatest breach of trust in our democratic institutions lies.After three years of being repeatedly told that ‘nothing has changed’, the time has come for ‘everything to change’.The British people are desperate for our country to leave the EU on st October. They are crying out for leadership which will put the country and our people first.The European Elections clearly reflect that and anybody who has knocked on doors or engaged the public in recent times knows that.We simply must move on and move out of the EU and fast.And in doing so we must move into a trade negotiation as has been outlined through numerous proposals over the last  months.Unfortunately Theresa May’s Cabinet showed themselves unwilling to listen to detailed proposals which would have a delivered the genuine Brexit the public voted for.So now the priority is to exit the European Union and move forward to negotiating a future relationship with protects British interests and keeps open the global prizes and benefits of Brexit which the British people voted for.Ministers who claim they are pro-brexit have failed to stand up for the . million who voted to leave and make that robust case to deliver the referendum mandate.The people were promised we would have left the EU months ago and that ‘no deal was better than a bad deal’.Having danced to the tune of the tune of the EU, spent billions of pounds on ‘no deal’ preparations, our country must just get on and leave the EU.Too many people in our political class lack confidence in our country and trust in the public. They have sought the comfort of the EU making our laws rather than making the decisions themselves. No wonder the British people feel betrayed.They expected the UK to leave the EU on th March as they were promised. Every day longer we remain in the EU adds salt to that wound.The governing class has broken trust in our politics.The British people voted to take back control and for Britain to be free, independent and self-governing again. Our destiny is as a global beacon of free trade, not a satellite of the EU.The Conservative Party must quit the navel-gazing and stop the rot of this Brexit betrayal.Those of us who believe in our Country and people, who respect our democratic and political freedoms, will continue to stand up for our liberty to make sure the days of betrayal are over.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: andrea leadsom no deal brexit steps opinion
story: I campaigned passionately for Leave in the  referendum and share the frustration of millions that the promise made three years ago has not been kept.It is vital that we leave the EU by October , without any further extension to that deadline.The EU tell us they will not reopen the Withdrawal Agreement. I take them at their word - so on that basis the Withdrawal Agreement Bill is dead.Instead, I have a pragmatic three-step plan - a plan to deliver Brexit in a way that protects citizens of the UK and the EU, delivers certainty to businesses, and maintains the integrity of our United Kingdom.No more preicating. No more fearmongering. And no more limbo. Just compassionate and decisive action that demonstrates leadership.My first step will be to take sensible measures to enshrine certain agreements into law, and to protect our people.I will immediately introduce key legislation to address this.First, I will introduce a citizens’ rights bill. EU citizens who have built lives here, and UK citizens who have made their homes in the EU must have the weight of uncertainty lted from their shoulders.Second, I will introduce a bill that locks in the mutually beneficial measures that have already been agreed between the UK and EU.This will cover areas like citizens’ rights in Gibraltar, our sovereign bases overseas, security and intelligence-sharing relationships, transport, data, and medicines.It is in everyone’s interest to put these agreed arrangements in place, and I believe many MPs would support this, regardless of how they voted in the referendum.The second step is to give businesses and industry the confidence and certainty they need to plan for a managed exit. I want them to be able to invest, hire, and innovate with renewed optimism.So we will ramp up preparations for our managed exit, focusing efforts on delivering alternative arrangements for the Northern Ireland border with the EU.Our continued strong bond with Northern Ireland will be protected.There are some sensitive sectors that rely upon ‘just-in-time’ supply chains, like automotive and aerospace. I know how important these are, and we will propose specic regulatory agreements with the EU for these.For other industries, like medicines and agri-foods, we will seek specic customs agreements on tarfs and non-tarf barriers. This will protect trade in the most vital goods and services but allow us to embrace new free trade deals around the world.At the core of this work will be open communication to Parliament, the public, and EU colleagues about progress, to build an environment of confidence and certainty. Parliament will receive regular updates, and households and businesses will receive communication from government that provides clear information about our managed exit.Transparency will be at the heart of everything I do - it’s what parliament expects, and it’s what the public deserves.The third step will be to lead a delegation of UK Ministers to meet with the EU Council and the proposed new EU Commissioners, to talk directly about the wide-ranging preparations we are making for a managed exit on October .Discussions will culminate in a UK EU summit, in September, in Belfast and Dublin, where the EU Council and proposed Commission will be invited to agree which measures we will all accept, to ensure a properly managed exit.As Prime Minister, I will not advocate an extension of any kind, and it will be clear that in all circumstances the UK will leave the EU at the end of October. With comprehensive arrangements in place, we will be prepared for any eventuality.We owe it to the country, and to our strong democratic tradition, to fulfil the instruction that our voters gave us.I am a passionate, pragmatic and positive believer in Brexit, and with my three-step plan, we can decisively leave the EU. We can demonstrate to the world that the UK remains a beacon for opportunity, fairness and democratic leadership. We can restore that vital trust between politics and the people.It’s not too late to take advantage of the opportunities we hoped for in voting Leave. It’s time to look forward we have an incredibly bright future ahead of us.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: prince george helpful stuns waitrose workers
story: The five-year-old has stunned staff by helping out alongside them to unload the groceries each time.He greets the van with dad William, , and their helpful approach has become well known among supermarket staff.They were praised for their constant offers to lug in the mammoth food order inside Anmer Hall.The family spend many weekends and holidays at their rural Norfolk home and have been spotted at beaches nearby.Anmer is close to Sandringham - the Queen’s country retreat.The insider explained: “It is rare for anyone to ever offers to carry deliveries inside.“So the Waitrose delivery staff were surprised and delighted to be greeted regularly by Prince William and Prince George.“George is always particularly helpful and is the one who asks each time what he can carry for them. He is a very inquisitive child.“They give him lighter bags. It shows how down-to-earth William is and that he wants his son to grow up being polite and helpful to others.”Kate, , is often spotted shopping at Waitrose branches in between deliveries.William’s down to earth parenting mirrors that of his late mother Diana.She would often take her sons on the bus or tube rather than in formal royal private cars.Prince George is reportedly also fascinated by volcanoes and dinosaurs and is said to boast an extensive collection of miniature police cars.His questioning of older royals has often got attention.He reportedly asked his uncle Prince Harry “why are you so quiet” when he was waiting to meet former US President Barack Obama.Kensington Palace declined to comment.   Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may d day hero letter
story: Capt Norman Skinner wrote to we Gladys and their two girls while preparing to liberate Europe in World War Two.He wrote: “My thoughts at this moment, in this lovely Saturday afternoon, are with you all now.“I can imagine you in the garden having tea with Janey and Anne getting ready to put them to bed.“Although I would give anything to be back with you, I have not yet had any wish at all to back down from the job we have to do.”Capt Skinner, , who was with the Royal Army Service Corps, landed on Sword Beach on June  but died the following day.Sixteen world leaders will hear PM Theresa May read the heartfelt note on Southsea Common at an event  produced by the BBC.Listening to her will be the Queen, US President Donald Trump, French President Emmanuel Macron and Germany’s Chancellor Angela Merkel.The commemorations are part of the th anniversary of the Normandy landings which were the start of Operation Overlord.More than , personnel will be involved in the commemorations in the UK and in France.And  veterans, all aged over , will retrace their journey across the Channel to northern France on Wednesday evening.Mrs May  said: “I am honoured to be able to mark the th anniversary of the landings alongside the veterans who were there.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: european leaders use d day
story: NewsEuropean leaders to use D-Day commemorations to go to war with Donald TrumpPrime Minister Theresa May, German Chancellor Angela Merkel, French President Emmanuel Macron and leaders of eight other member nations are expected to use the D-Day commemorations to confront himShareCommentsByNigel NelsonPolitical Editor:,  JUN NewsMr Trump is upset that only five of the  NATO nations – including us – spend two per cent of national income on defence "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWestern leaders will use D-Day commemorations here this week to go to war with Donald Trump over his threats to collapse NATO.Prime Minister Theresa May , German Chancellor Angela Merkel, French President Emmanuel Macron and leaders of eight other member nations are expected to team up to confront the controversial US President.Mr Trump is upset that only five of the  NATO nations – including us – spend two per cent of national income on defence. And he is threatening to pull out unless it changes. The intervention during D-Day events comes as we host the biggest gathering of world leaders outside a formal summit since the  Olympics. The highlight of the th anniversary will be a military spectacle on Southsea Common, Hants, on Wednesday – the last day of Mr Trump’s state visit.    A source said: “Leaders will lunch, where they are expected to discuss the enduring importance of the Western alliance and the values that underpin it for our security and prosperity today.” America pays two-thirds of the tab for NATO, set up in the Cold War to tackle Russia and Warsaw Pact nations. He has said: “The US is paying for Europe’s protection. NATO countries must pay MORE, the US must pay LESS. Very unfair!” Wednesday’s spectacular, with a Red Arrows and Spitfire flypast, will be opened by the Queen and Prince Charles.    The PM said: “It is right we reflect on and celebrate the cooperation that helped secure the freedom we cherish today.”Meanwhile, Taylor Swt blasted Mr Trump’s stance on pro-LGBT laws.The pop star, , wants fans to urge their senators to back the Equality Act, which was passed by the House of Representatives. She said: “I reject the President’s stance that his administration ‘supports equal treatment’ but the Equality Act ‘in its current form is filled with poison pills that threaten to undermine parental and conscience rights’.”

title: rogue bosses who wont pay
story: NewsRogue bosses who wont pay minimum wage will no longer be named and shamedEXCLUSIVE: The Tories are letting down low-paid workers by not shaming companies who refuse to pay the minimum wageShareCommentsByKeir Mudie:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsGovernment ministers admit they have stopped outing firms who do not pay the minimum wage "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTory ministers have admitted to Labour MP Stephanie Peacock that they are no longer ‘naming and shaming’ employers who illegally fail to pay workers the minimum wage. The government slipped out news that they were reviewing the practice over Christmas in , and now confirmed that they will not name any employers caught breaking the law by underpaying staff while that review is ongoing. Business Minister Kelly Tolhurst told Ms Peacock that there was “no set completion date” for the review, which has now taken nearly six months. Ms Peacock MP said: “This admission makes clear that the Tories are soft on rogue bosses, and that ordinary working people just can’t rely on this government to protect their most basic rights. “The minimum wage has lted pay for millions, but it won’t workit’s not enforced.    There should be no hiding place for criminal employers who refuse to follow the law, and the government should be cracking down not backing down.” In April this year, the Low Pay Commission called on the government to resume ‘naming and shaming’ as part of a package to crack down on bad bosses, warning that over , workers were illegally underpaid last year. The last official ‘naming’ round was on  July , nearly a year ago, when  employers found to have underpaid , UK workers by a total of £.m were publicly revealed. The amount was the largest identied by HMRC in any single naming list and generated record fines.

title: i baby sick twisted double
story: NewsI had a baby with sick and twisted double murderer who burnt woman aliveDouble killer Stephen Unwins ex Rachel Edmundson says Quyen Nguyens death may have been preventedhe had been monitored by the Probation ServiceShareByDan WarburtonKevin Donald:,  JUN NewsRachel Edmundson says her ex Stephen Unwin was never visited by a probation officer following his release from prison "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman who had a baby with double murderer Stephen Unwin last night asked: “Why was he free to kill again ” Rachel Edmundson spoke out after an inquest this week heard how convicted killer Unwin, , raped and burned to death a young mum while he should have been monitored by the Probation Service. Rachel, , had just split from Unwin when he and a prison pal slaughtered nail technician Quyen Nguyen, , after torturing her for five hours. Rachel last night told the Sunday People: “If the Probation Service had done their jobs he would not have been able to kill anyone . “In the five years I was with him I NEVER saw a probation officer visit our home or question who he was mixing with. “I feel so sorry for the family of the girl he murdered. “It preys on my mind constantly, I can’t sleep because I’m running dferent scenarios around in my mind, trying to imagine what went on in that house. “It horries me that the man I fell for, had a five year relationship with and had a daughter with was capable of that kind of sick, twisted cruelty.” Rachel got together with Unwin after he was freed following a jail stretch for murdering retired pharmacist Jack Greenwell, .    After having a baby Rachel split with Unwin and he teamed up with another freed murderer, former cellmate John McFall, . The pair lured Quyen to a business meeting and beat her up and sexually abused her for hours. Then they bundled her in the back of her car, drove it down a secluded track, splashed petrol over her and set her on fire while she was still alive. The evil pair, who took a chilling selfie picture as they drove away, are now serving whole le sentences – meaning they will die in jail. Rachel told the Sunday People: “Quyens’s death could have been avoidedpeople had checked on what he was doing and who he was with.” “I’m preparing myself for the day when I have to tell my daughter what sort of person her father is. I’ve no idea how I’ll find the words. “At the moment all I’ve told her is that he did something bad and had to go to the naughty boys’ home.”  Unwin carried out his second murder despite police logging  incidents involving him in five years after his release for killing the OAP in a bid to get drugs. Northumbria police also failed to report claims he had threatened to rape a woman to the probation service, the inquest in Sunderland was told. Rachel said: “When Stephen first came out of prison he had to go to meetings with the probation service once a week.I went along with him a number of times and all the probation worker was interested in was whether he was working and whether his le at home was settled. “In all the time we lived together I don’t remember any spot checks being carried out at home, to my knowledge we were never visited by the probation service. “He was never asked who he was associating with and I’m certain they had no idea he was with John McFall on a daily basis. “They were living together while both were on le licence and no one in authority had a clue.” Rachel, of Sunderland, met Unwin when they were both  and they dated in . She was reintroduced to him through a mutual friend in  by which time he was in prison for murdering Mr Greenwell. Unwin had been sentenced to le at Newcastle upon Tyne Crown Court in  but Rachel was unaware why he was in prison when she started to write to him.    She said: “He told me why he was in jail in a phone call. “He told me Mr Greenwell came at him with a kne and he then turned it on him, which I now know was nonsense.I was deeply shaken and didn’t know what to do. “But he told me that he was completely rehabilitated, that he’d turned his le around in prison and learnt new skills he could use on the outside.” Unwin was moved from Hull jail to an open prison in Lincolnshire as he was prepared for his release in  after serving  years. Rachel said: “I wasn’t there when he was released but over a few months he convinced me he was a truly changed character and he moved into my home. “One of the things that made me think he was a changed man was his desire to become a father.He felt he had missed some of his best years in prison and said he didn’t want his chance to have a child to pass him by.”    Their daughter was born three years ago. Rachel said: “She idolised Stephen and he loved her. “He set up his own business as a handyman. It seemed as though we were setting out on a normal family le but that didn’t last long.” She discovered Unwin had been trying to meet up with other women. Their relationship ended in May  although they remained on civil terms for their daughter’s sake. But on August  of the same year his true nature was revealed. She said: “My eldest daughter’s boyfriend drove past the house where Stephen was living and McFall was staying.He said there were police all over the place.  “The following day I saw on the news that the young lady’s body had been found in a burning car and I instinctively knew it was him. “I felt physically sick with the horror of it – and that’s before I knew the details of what those animals had done to that poor girl.”Unwin had got to know hard-working Quyen when he and McFall, from Blackpool, worked on properties that she rented out. Rachel said: “Despite the terrible things he has done Stephen could be very convincing that he was a changed man, a decent man. “He seemed to have fooled his probation officer because she seemed perfectly happy with him and in no hurry to see him more than once a month. “With hindsight I wish I had raised the alarm but he’s so manipulative that I thought he was rehabilitated and starting over. “When I heard the evidence from the inquest that he had threatened to rape someone a month before the murder I was devastated. “It made me wonder whether I could have done something but I didn’t see the danger he still presented.” A senior officer told this week’s inquest that the police unit monitoring offenders struggled under “unmanageable workloads”. And the probation officer monitoring Unwin said her office was in chaos after cutbacks. The inquest is expected to finish next week. But for Rachel the verdict will be irrelevant – and too late for victim Quyen. Rachel said: “I hope Stephen and McFall are tortured in jail because that’s what they deserve.” Shambles for Grayling The Probation Service is being brought back under public control after a disastrous part- privatisation. The current system was introduced by then- justice secretary Chris Grayling in . But the chief inspector of probation, Dame Glenys Stacey, has described it as “irredeemably flawed”. Offenders on probation were charged with  murders between  and . Over the same period they were also charged with  attempted murders and, rapes or attempted rapes. The Ministry of Justice said: “Serious further offences are very rare but each one is taken extremely seriously and investigated fully to identy lessons.”

story: NewsFashion student, , becomes youngest female HGV driver in the UKJodie Lawson got the drive to get behind the wheel from her dad, Colin Lawson who runs the trucking company Colin Lawson TransportShareByGary Carter:,  JUN NewsJodie Lawson, , has passed HGV driving test first time to become a qualied trucker "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA fashion student has become the youngest female HGV driver in the UK. Jodie Lawson, , got the drive to get behind the wheel from her dad, Colin. The NESCol textile and fashion student grew up watching the lorries in the yard of her father’s trucking company, Colin Lawson Transport in Altens. Now Aberdeen-based Jodie can get behind the wheel after passing her tests. Jodie said: “I have been visiting my dad’s business ever since I was a little girl and I was always interested in working in the yard. “I had talked about getting my licence but I never thought I would actually get it.”    After celebrating her th birthday in January, Jodie started her training in March before passing her Class  and Class  HGV training on the first attempt in May. She added: “I had a few lessons driving the trucks with a few of the drivers who would take me out on jobs with them. “I was able to get some practice in that way, since it’s quite dferent from a regular car. “I normally drive a little car so the transition to driving an HGV was nerve-wracking.”    The second-year fashion student said learning to drive a lorry was challenging and she was “determined” to pass. “The most challenging bit was learning to rethink how much space you take up on the road. “You’re quite high up when you’re sitting in the lorry and there’s a lot of thinking.” Jodie said she hopes her story will encourage other women to follow in her footsteps and “break the stereotype” of lorry drivers. She said: “You always think of men when you see a lorry or think of a man doing all of the heavy lting. When we’re out on jobs people are really shocked to see me because that’s not what you normally expect. Some of my friends couldn’t believe it.    “At first, I kept talking about my test quiet because I thought I wouldn’t go through with it, but when I told them they were really, really shocked. “I want to break the stereotype and I really like that, maybe, someone can see my story and feel motivated to do this. “I hope more girls and older women who are out there who want to do this will do so. “My advice would be to just go for it. Don’t be scared because when you’re up there in that lorry it’s an amazing feeling – it’s ace.”

title: grandparents cycle 12000 miles cumbria
story: NewsGrandparents cycle , MILES from Cumbria to China to challenge themselvesIncredible couple in their s slept in a tent for  months during amazing journey — and ed home by shipping containerShareCommentsByPoppy Danby:,  MAY NewsRemarkable Peter and Chris have ed from one of the most incredible treks imaginable and they did it in their s "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen pensioners Chris and Peter Lloyd decided they wanted a bit more adventure in their lives, they ended up getting a little ­carried away... The intrepid couple cycled from Hadrian’s Wall to the Great Wall of China, covering a gruelling , miles in  months. They cycled every day and camped at night, enduring temperatures that fell to minus C in Northern China and rose to C in the deserts of Uzbekistan. In some countries they struggled to find food and in Tajikistan had to survive on biscuits for three days. Chris, , says: “Sometimes I really wanted to be at home by the wood burning stove with a glass of wine, but, apart from that, we didn’t miss anything.” Peter, , chips in: “Apart from rhubarb crumble...”    The couple, who live near Hadrian’s Wall in Carlisle, Cumbria, first came up with the idea for the trip in . Chris says: “We weren’t unhappy but we were healthy enough – so we wanted to challenge ourselves.” Although they had always cycled for fun, they were not serious about it. Peter says: “We didn’t dress in Lycra and go out on our bikes every weekend. But all our lives, we’d cycled to work or the shops.”  They bought Thorn touring bikes, got a train to Greece and cycled back as a test run. Chris says: “It was fantastic.” So they began planning their journey to China. The couple, who have two sons, and four grandchildren, set off in January .Chris says: “We had terrible weather . So when we got to Hungary, we went to a mineral spa to relax. But Peter tripped and broke his femur.”   He had surgery before they flew back to the UK but seven months later, on October , , they set off again. Chris says: “We had one change of clothes, waterproofs, a stove, pans and cutlery. It was three weeks before we reached our first country, France, when things began to feel more real.” They travelled through Europe, the Middle East and Asia before reaching the Great Wall on November , . Chris says: “The weather was a bit unnerving sometimes. The wind was so strong in Northern China that we were nearly knocked off our bikes. “The desert in Uzbekistan was C. So, having enough water and staying cool was a problem.”  They also camped every night and Chris says: “I have a sixth sense for finding good places. “But sometimes we struggled and in Italy we had to camp by the side of the road and were visited by the police. In Turkey, we camped in a cave and lit a fire, just like cavemen. It was very special.” Chris says seeing the Great Wall was “very emotional”.  She says: “I was happy and a bit surprised that we’d made it. There were lots of times when I thought we wouldn’t.” They cycled on through Laos, ­Thailand, Malaysia and Singapore, before getting on a container ship back to the UK.  Chris says: “We didn’t want to fly because it’s not environmentally friendly. It took three weeks.” Chris and Peter finally arrived back in England on April  and got home on May  after cycling to Cumbria.  Chris says: “The sun was shining and our family cycled to meet us.” Reflecting on the trip, Peter says: “People are great all over the world. If more of us got out of our armchairs and saw that, then the world would be a much nicer place.” Countries they visited  They set out from northern England, then visited France, Italy, Greece, Turkey, Georgia, Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, Kyrgyzstan, China, Laos, Thailand, Malaysia and Singapore. Then it was on to a shipping container vessel via: Indian Ocean, Arabian Sea, Somalia, Mediterranean Sea, Gibraltar, Bay of Biscay.

title: inside manchesters coolest council estate
story: NewsInside Manchesters coolest council estate with its VERY appealing perksThe Smithfield Estate, which lies in Manchesters famous Northern Quarter, boasts free city centre parking and open garden spaceShareCommentsByLata YedroudjJill Burdett:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsThe Smithfield Estate lies in Manchesters Northern Quarter "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Manchester has a council estate which boasts free city centre parking and low service charges - and occasionally, some properties are put on the market. The Smithfield Estate lies in Manchesteraposs famous Northern Quarter and was built by Manchester City Council in the s.With its charming exterior, the red brick cluster of homes but looks nothing like your typical council housing. The buildingaposs service charges are capped at £ per quarter, a much lower fee than new building apartments in the town with a £ a month fee. Most of the  or so houses are rented out through Northwards Housing, although around  have been purchase through Right to Buy.  Rachel Hoy bought home in December  and spent three months renovating her place into a five-star abode. Employing a group of builders, Rachel knocked down walls to open up more space and installed a new kitchen and bathroom.Rachel told Manchester Evening News : “I work in property development and I quickly learned it is much harder doing your own project! I moved in three months later and genuinely loved living there.”While renovating her house, she met her neighbours Mani and Celine Keleher who were also in the processing of upgrading their apartments.    Rachel added: “We ended up using the same builders so would often end up in the pub comparing notes and either crying into our beer or toasting a job well done!” Mani, owner of ONE% Microlot Coffees, said: “Like Rachel we gutted the place and opened it up to make it more liveable. We put in a new kitchen and bathroom and added some colour. “And the outside space is ridiculously huge – a rare thing in the centre of the city. We even have a shed. And it is lovely to be surrounded by trees in the heart of the city centre.” Now, both Rachel and The Kelehers have put up their one-bedroom apartments for sale each priced at £,.  Rachel said: “I got a new job and now work in Dublin. The flat is my pride and joy and I did not want to rent it out I would like someone to live in it and love it as much as I did. Make their own mark and there is huge potential outside.” Speaking about moving away from the city, Mani said: “We are looking at what the future holds. But Smithfield has a real sense of community neighbours have been here  years and really care about the place. It is an iconic part of the Northern Quarter and helps make the area what it is.” Manchester City Council is running a £, project to replace windows and doors in the estate as well as installing a new gate system. As Oliver Dolan from agents JLL added: “These apartments don’t come up for sale very often and it’s dficult to find a property right in the city centre with this amount of outside space.  “Both apartments have been refurbished to a really high standard throughout and the added benefit of permit parking makes then unique.” The Manchester City Council still owns two third of the properties but occasionally, houses do come up for rent or sale. A three bedroom maisonette has recently been put up for sale at £, a month.

title: saira khan beauty skin deep
story: NewsopinionSaira Khan: Beauty is skin deep with lack of ersity in Miss India pageantThere is an obsession among South Asian women to have fairer skin, and it starts the moment you are bornShareCommentsBySaira Khan:,  JUN NewsopinionThe Miss India contest has been slammed for all the contestants looking identical "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOn a visit to Pakistan a few years ago, a friend of mine treated me to a ­facial in a local salon. I was expecting the usual cleanse, tone and moisturise routine with some lovely smelling lotions and potions. But on the Indian sub-continent, they do facials a little dferently – as I found out to my horror when I could smell bleach on my skin. The beautician was unfazed when I demanded to know what she had used on my face. “It’s just skin whitening, your skin will look fair and lovely afterwards.” I was pretty happy with the way it looked before, thank you very much!    It’s sad to say, but there is an obsession among South Asian women to have fairer skin, and it starts the moment you are born.Relatives openly talk about how “dark” or “white” a baby is... the lighter the better because inthat culture it leads to better opportunities in le – marriage, jobs etc.So against this background is it any wonder that the organisers of this year’s Miss India competition have come under fire for having a line-up of contestants that one Twitter user said looked like “an ad for the Aryan nation”  Looking at the photo of the  very pale, albeit very beautul, finalists, the lack of ersity from such a erse country is appalling. And big business is capitalising on this cultural stigma. Multi-national cosmetics brands have found a lucrative market – global spending on skin lightening is projected to triple to US. billion by , according to a  report by research firm Global Industry Analysts. When I was given the bleach facial, I felt my sensitive skin ­tightening and burning. The health risks of using skin- whitening products over a long period of time are staggering. Research shows that steroids contained in these creams can lead to thinning of the skin, bruising or tearing, enlarged blood vessels, increased hair growth in treated areas, steroid dependence, and pustular psoriasis.    Charming. As an Asian woman, I find it heartbreaking that some women resort to slathering themselves in toxic potions in order to feel beautul – or even accepted. What is even more tragic is when this practice is carried out by children. The NSPCC carried out research that showed British schoolkids are whitening their skin with make-up to avoid being bullied or racially abused. I grew up in Britain during the s and s being ashamed of my skin colour, constantly teased and bullied for being dferent. So I could never understand why so many white people spend so much money on tanning products and expensive holidays to get my brown skin. I could not be happier in my own skin now. Brains, attitude, kindness and le experiences are what count. Why are we risking our lives to look like someone

story: NewsSicko used Snapchat and Instagram to find, groom and abuse young girlThe Birmingham man was jailed for human trafficking and rape offences at Shrewsbury Crown CourtShareByGary Carter:,  JUN NewsThe -year-old was found guilty of two counts of human trafficking and one count of rape "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA pervert used Snapchat and Instagram to find, groom and abuse a young girl. Ghamer Sulayman used the social media apps to first make contact with his young victim. He would go on to sleep with the -year-old girl on numerous occasions. The -year-old plied her with alcohol and drugs before ordering her to have sex with multiple men and threatening to throw her onto the streetsshe didnapost comply. Sulayman was eventually brought to justice and jailed for ten years at the end of a trial at Shrewsbury Crown Court.  Judge Peter Barrie said: You didnapost have any genuine affection for her. Nobody who had any genuine affection for her could have contemplated for even a moment getting her involved in what you did to her. In the week he was convicted of two counts of human trafficking and one count of rape, police told of how they tracked him down and how the courage of the victim saw her sick abuser brought to justice. Sulayman found his victim through social media and quickly convinced her to travel with him and several other men to Birmingham from her grandparentaposs home in Telford, Shropshire on July , . Staying in a Birmingham house the abuser told the victim to sleep with multiple men or face a night on the streets. She was then dumped at a train station the next day to make her own way back to Telford. Later that month the two met up in a Telford supermarket car park on several occasions to have sex with the girlaposs approval, although she was too young to legally consent. On some occasions other men would be present at the car park and Sulayman “pimped” her to his friends infor favours. Plying the underage girl with cannabis and alcohol, the offender ignored her pleas when she said she didnapost want to have sex. Following the prosecution Chief Superintendent Tom Harding told of how the investigation began with a missing persons report. A family member had called police just after pm on July , , to report the girl absence - the fth time she had been reported missing to the force. At pm on July  the girl contact her family to say she was in Birmingham and would be getting the train home.  Chief Supt Harding said that at the time the victim was already working with a team designed to stop youngsters from being abused. The Children Abused Through Exploitation was set up specically to help youngsters who may be at risk from groomers and sexual predators. Chief Supt Harding said: “We suspected she was being exploited, however she did not wish to speak to police about what had taken place while she was missing and in turn she did not want us to proceed with a prosecution.” The police chief launched an investigation despite her reluctance., uncovering CCTV footage that showed the teenager with the -year-old. He said: “We managed to pinpoint the car she was picked up in at Asda. “That was identied through detailed inquiries as being at Corley service station on the M. Some CCTV shows Sulayman entering the shop in the petrol station and another shows him ing to the vehicle. “This shows the trafficking nature of the offence.” A search of the victim’s home also turned up names and phone numbers. Chief Supt Harding said: “As part of that work we identied telephone numbers and in turn established that contact had been made through social media – Snapchat and Instagram . We believed that on the night the girl went missing she was taken to hotels in Birmingham city centre.”  The police chief explained how Sulayman had tried over time to get the girl in a position where she could be abused. He said: “She had been in contact with this man for five months before the missing episode which highlights the ‘boyfriend’ type model. The first arrests in relation to the case took place in March , and it was a further ten months and  police interviews before charges followed. Chief Supt Harding said: “The victim would not provide us with an account of what took place so we were having to build up a picture of her movements and those of Sulayman over a period of time. “Also, during that period suspects were interviewed  times with each lasting approximately two hours. She eventually felt able to open up following support from the police. As well as the three guilty rulings, Sulayman was cleared on six counts of rape and one of human trafficking at the judge’s direction. Ayad Hizam and Saleh Qasem, of Balsall Heath, Birmingham, were both found not guilty of offences relating to the victim. Detective Constable Steve Parton, who was the officer in charge of the investigation praised the victim, who is now , for her strength. He also commended the support teams that had worked with her. He said: “The victim in this case has shown great courage and bravery, it has not been easy and I hope the verdict offers some solace to her as she now moves forward in her le. “I’d also like to recognise the fantastic support Telford  Wrekin Council’s CATE team.has provided and have no doubt we would not be where we are today without the work they carried out.” A West Mercia Police spokesman urged sexual assault victims to call    or visit www.victimadviceline.org.uk.
